@elmlang devs: what are your answers to these questions? And how do you think we can better communicate with the mainstream front-end community?

This is why I'm excited about @rhg_dev's Elm Land framework project. He seems to be asking questions like:

‚Ä¢ What obstacles do JS devs meet when they try Elm?
‚Ä¢ What is unfamiliar or hard to do?
‚Ä¢ How can we make delightful experiences?
‚Ä¢ How can we make Elm easy to try?

I think Elm itself has done an extremely good job at achieving these design goals.

But I often wonder how the tooling and communication efforts in the Elm community could appeal better to JavaScript developers and their problems.

üîß Tooling

Evan emphasized the importance of leveraging Elm's advantages to create "unique and delightful experiences".

By providing experiences like the time-travel debugger and friendly error messages, Elm could appeal to its audience and be adopted as a mainstream language.

üó£ Communication

Evan asked the audience to imagine themselves as a developer comparing the competing sales pitches of a set of language tools.

He demonstrated that communication with an audience needs to be centered on the needs of that audience, not the features of the tool.

In his talk (https://t.co/xR6Qlj0npb), Evan expanded on several areas of his proposed strategy for promoting adoption, that he called "User-focused Design in Elm".

The two I want to focus on are Communication and Tooling.

A convention should be:

üí° Clear
The reader should immediately understand what it means

üíÅ Easy
Beginning developers should be able to immediately use it

üîß Useful
It should promote code that is easy to understand and change

Conventions reduce decision fatigue and promote helpful practices.

Without conventions, Msg names often vary unhelpfully, describing:
‚Ä¢ Events that have happened
‚Ä¢ Behaviors that should happen
‚Ä¢ Data types involved in an event

üîÅ Repeat

Having proved Elm's benefits, identify more problem areas and run similar experiments.

Little by little, you can introduce Elm into your codebase more extensively.

üëÑ Teach others

Has your experiment successfully solved your company's problem? Now is your opportunity to explain Elm's technical benefits.

Show others on your team what you did, and make yourself available as an educational resource.

üî¨ Run an experiment

Attempt to use Elm to solve one of the problem areas you identified.

Choose something that's small in scope, and easy to revert. This way, the risk will be as small as it can be.

üò± Identify a problem area in your application

Does your project have any bug-ridden features that constantly divert resources and frustrate your team?

These are great opportunities to demonstrate‚Äînot argue‚ÄîElm's reliability.

üö´ Avoid abstract arguments

It can be tempting to try to convince your team to use Elm when its merits seem clear to you.

But this will not help others to see Elm as a benefit more than a cost‚Äîand no argument you make will be as convincing as proof.

I'm lucky to say I've been able to use @elmlang at my jobs because of engineering leadership who saw its value.

But most companies need to be convinced of why they should take a chance on Elm.

ü§π Try different approaches

Given a domain concept, how many ways could you model it, and with what other data types?

In Elm, refactoring is aided by the compiler! Change your model, and see how different attempts can make your code easier or harder to work with.

‚ùì Use type variables as a last resort

Type variables can be helpful abstraction tools. But does your custom type really need to allow for any possible type to be used?

Try starting from a more constrained set first, and use a type variable only if it's necessary.

ü§î Reconsider primitive types

You may be used to using `Bool`s and `String`s in other languages.

But sometimes `String`s don't constrain possible values enough.

`Bool`s are not descriptive, and they won't allow for the addition of further options if they come up.

ü§∑ Use `Maybe` as rarely as possible

Since all cases must be handled explicitly, `Maybe`s can multiply the conditions to handle and make your code hard to work with.

When nullable data starts accumulating, consider a custom type to create guarantees.

‚úÖ Use custom types for conditional data

Some data is only present in a particular case.

If our type is `Animal`, a `Fish` has no `Feathers`, and a `Bird` has no `Scales`. These constraints are possible in Elm!

Use custom types to include conditional data only when needed.

In @elmlang, modeling data accurately is more valuable than writing good algorithms.

With clear data modeling, errors that are possible in your program will be fewer, and your codebase more coherent. But doing it well can be a hard skill to develop!

ü™Ñ Code generation

One of my favorite features allows you to generate the boilerplate for destructuring a type.

Just run the command and it creates all the branches you need.

It can also generate JSON decoders for a given type!

üóÉ Auto-import / Auto expose

If you need a function, just use it‚Äîthe editor will give you the option to add an import without scrolling to the top of your file.

It can also expose/un-expose code defined in your module.

üóë Detect unused code

Because of Elm's language design, it's easy to tell via static analysis whether code is ever used.

Unused imports, function, types, and variants show up in gray in your editor‚Äîno need to even run a command to find them!

‚úçÔ∏è Rename all instances

Similarly, the type-aware find-and-replace applies to all usages and all type annotations.

Changing names is as easy as it can be‚Äîrename any of your functions, types, and type variants.

üïµÔ∏è Find all usages

Highlight a type or function, and the editor will find all usages of it throughout your codebase.

It uses the AST, so it's type-aware‚Äîmuch more effective than text-based search.

One of the things I like about Elm's culture is that clever solutions like mine tend to seem like they might be a bad idea.

The design of the language encourages you to write in a simple and sensible way‚Äîstick to the patterns and chances are you'll have a maintainable program.

As for the second case, the "record-updater as an argument" interface has been a source of confusion in our codebase for some time because of its ergonomics in complex cases.

Generating the functions didn't make these cases any easier to understand.

In the first case, I think the better option would be to model a `Subscription` as an opaque type, so that nested record updating was not possible.

Then we could design the `Subscription` module to include a helper function that made updating its `Transaction`s easier.

There were two cases where we used these record-updater functions:

1) Updating nested records that model data (e.g. a `Subscription` with a `List Transaction`)

2) Passing record-updater functions as arguments (mostly for using a third-party library)

We started adopting this pattern because of its ease of use.

Our team grew, and I found myself explaining to others what these magical functions were and how to work with the script.

The usefulness wasn't usually worth the obscurity of the process.

My clever solution was to write a shell script that let me write the "record-updater" function I wished I had, of the form:

`withUpdatedX` (where `X` is the field to update)

The script scanned for instances of these, and generated the corresponding functions in a module.

In @elmlang it's hard to update nested records. Some people (including me) have complained about this.

A few years ago, I wrote some code to solve this "problem". Looking back, I wish I had approached it differently. üßµ

üõ† How can tools help us?

When I read these ideas, I thought of static analysis tools like @jfmengels's `elm-review`.

Given a project lexicon and a list of name molds, could a rule be written to evaluate whether new names used in a PR were consistent, and suggest improvements?

üí´ How can we choose better names?

Review names after code has been written, when you have more mental space.

Keep a "project lexicon" to helpfully constrain word options for consistency.

Review the name molds your project uses and choose ones to adhere to intentionally.

üìö Word choice

Using dictionary words vs. letters or abbreviations makes names easier to understand.

Using consistent words for the same idea helps the long-term memory.

Using multiple words for the same idea creates ambiguity (e.g. "are these the same, or subtly different?")

üç± Patterns for naming

Programmers use "name molds"‚Äîtemplates that words fit into.

Here is the same naming idea, with different molds used: `maxX`, `maxXPerY`, `maxNumberOfX`, `maxXAmount`, "yXLimit`

Keeping molds consistent in code helps the long-term memory.

‚öôÔ∏è How good names work

Good names support "chunking", a compression method aided by the short-term memory.

Clear names with well-chosen words help the long-term memory make connections to a problem domain.

Names with consistent syntactical formats are easier to process.

üêõ Code with bad names has more bugs

Research has found a statistically significant correlation between bug frequency and bad names.

"Bad names" includes names with syntactic issues, and ones that use non-dictionary words.

ü§∑ Why name things well?

Names make up the majority of code‚Äî72% of a large typical codebase.

Naming issues come up often‚Äîthey were found in 25% of code reviews studied.

Names affect debugging‚Äîin studies, developers could find 19% more bugs when reading code with good names.

üòì Why is naming hard?

Naming happens while solving problems, when we are using our brains the most and have little mental energy to spare.

And name choice isn't consistent‚Äîin studies, two programmers only chose the same name for a variable or method 7% of the time.

Have you ever said "naming things is hard!", but didn't know what to do about it?

I've been reading @Felienne's book and I've learned that improving names in your codebase may be more straightforward than you think!

Here are a few things about names in code that surprised me:

üö´ Move deprecated modules into a Deprecated directory

Are a module's types and functions the current "best practice" in your codebase? The answer isn't always clear.

Keep a `Deprecated` directory and move outdated modules there if they can't be removed yet.

üéØ Rename modules accurately

Give your code a change to be findable when it's needed!

Make sure your modules are named for the types and helper functions they contain.

üå± Move a type and its functions into a new module

Module interfaces are clearest when they focus on a single data type and its helper functions.

When you see new types and helper functions for then begin to show up, move them into their own module.

‚Ü™Ô∏è Extract named functions

Sometimes you need complicated functions that involve multiple steps. But these can be hard to understand.

Extract each step into its own named functions, so that the complex function can be skimmed at a high level.

üêú Reduce function arguments to their minimum

Don't pass your entire `Model` to a function when it only needs a small subset.

Instead, use extensible record arguments, or pass data in separately.

This makes your functions easier to rule out as causes of errors when debugging.

‚úçÔ∏è Add type annotations

What data does a given function operate on?

Adding a type annotation answers this question, and makes Elm's compiler errors more accurate.

VS Code and IntelliJ both let you automatically generate annotations, making this easier.

Code clarity means less time fixing problems‚Äîespecially in large codebases. But what habits are worth the effort? 

Here are 6 simple refactors to continually make to increase the clarity of your @elmlang code:

@RantingOwl For me, genders are groupings of traits that we're expected to conform to. Some are physical, and some are behavioral. I started looking at "man" and thought, what traits does this label contain? How do I feel about each of them? And I tried to form intentions about each one.

üìå Minimal

In the Elm core libraries, there is mostly only one way of doing something (e.g. rendering HTML, producing an HTTP request, parsing, etc.). This minimalism means easier communication between developers on a project.

üå≥ Environmentally friendly

Elm's compiled asset sizes are the smallest among React, Vue, and Angular 2. If all web applications used Elm, their download size would be smaller on average by a factor of (at least) 2.5.

üî¨ Thorough

Elm's custom types allow you to model your domain much more precisely and correctly than is capable with JavaScript objects. This allows program states to be more accurate and less capable of producing errors.

‚õ∞Ô∏è Long-lasting

Some applications are cheaper to rebuild than to refactor. But Elm applications are easy to refactor confidently, which means codebases can remain useful longer.

‚öñÔ∏è Honest

Elm requires you to handle all cases of your application state. This removes the possibility of runtime errors due to unhandled cases.

üï∂Ô∏è Unobtrusive

Most Elm developers use `elm-format`, an automatic formatting tool that is standardized and non-configurable by design. So the layout of most Elm code will not surprise you.

üí° Understandable

Elm is easy to learn, and its lack of side-effects makes application code easier to understand, maintain and debug.

üè∫ Aesthetic

Members of the Elm community are quick to express the emotional satisfaction of refactoring huge parts of their codebase and arriving at a working result.

üî® Useful

Elm's static types and pure functions create numerous guarantees, making software development predictable and scalable.

üí• Innovative

Elm brings pure functional programming to front-end web development. Front-end had never been served by this paradigm before.

Let's review each principle.

Good design:
üí• Is innovative
üî® Makes a product useful
üè∫ Is aesthetic
üí° Makes a product understandable
üï∂Ô∏è Is unobtrusive
‚öñÔ∏è Is honest
‚õ∞Ô∏è Is long-lasting
üî¨ Is thorough
üå≥ Is environmentally friendly
üìå Is as little design as possible

My coworkers who work on open-source projects (@mech_elephant and @rhg_dev) seem to use a similar technique.

They'll switch from work on a large project to building a small game, library, or experiment, rotating between projects to stay active and engaged.
This could mean, in the midst of a long project at work, starting my day by taking an hour to fix a bug that's been bothering me and my team‚Äîsimple and satisfying.
I find a good way to give myself more energy in the midst of a long-running project is to find something small and finish it.

For me, often the hardest part of a long project isn't the technical challenge‚Äîit's maintaining my enthusiasm.

Rest is essential, but taking a break doesn't give you more enthusiasm for a project‚Äîcompleting something does.

When I was a kid, my dad told me some advice about creativity that I'll never forget:

Using Elm gives me the feeling that i'm working with someone patient, smart, and sympathetic.

So more than any other design feature, I like that Elm's designed with an understanding that software is hard.

And it's designed to do all it can to make it as easy as it can be.

Being smart is a big expectation of the job of writing code.

And we as programmers are sometimes reluctant to admit that there's only so smart we can be.

But we all have our mental limits, and Elm is considerate of them.

As projects get complicated, they get harder. There are more and more things to think about.

That's hard enough‚Äîwriting code shouldn't be any harder than it needs to be.

All of these design choices in Elm follow logically from that idea.

Elm's technical innovation was to bring ideas from the ML family of languages to front-end web dev, which had mostly just seen various elaborations on JavaScript.

But I think the real innovation is in the considerate spirit of its design.

I can refactor huge parts of my application's design confidently and it still works.

And the design of the Elm package system means I can upgrade my dependencies and be sure they will still work.

So the foundation of my Elm application is stable.

When I read a function annotation in Elm, I know, at a glance, exactly what that function can and can't change in my program state.

And I know it will always behave the same way with the same inputs.

So my Elm code is easy to think about.

Why is @elmlang good? Is it because:
- It's delightful?
- It creates no runtime exceptions?
- You can refactor fearlessly?
- It has friendly error messages?

These are all true. But I think more than anything, it's because Elm is kind.

ü§ù Decide together how you want to communicate

Talk with your team about how reviews should be conducted and problems you run into. 

What would you like to hear in reviews more often? What's frustrated you in the past? Ask your team and find solutions to those issues together.

üëØ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Avoid impasses with collaboration

I‚Äôve seen many code reviews turn unproductive as they spiraled into abstract debates about which of two possible choices is better.

Don't argue principles. Take the opportunity to align by working together on a concrete example.

üéØ Align on goals by making them clear

Miscommunications during PRs can lead to unproductive debates and flaring tempers. Many miscommunications result from incorrect assumptions about the goal of the work. 

Avoid this by making goals explicit in the PR description every time.

ü•∞ Show your appreciation generously

Dismissing contributions or concerns as unimportant is a sure and easy way to make people feel disrespected.

But with a little attention, you can form the opposite habit: the first thing you say should acknowledge the other person.

ü•ä Don‚Äôt judge the code

It can feel good to judge code you don't like. But you can't pass judgment on a language or piece of code without also judging the intelligence and capability of the people involved in it.

So don‚Äôt say ‚Äúthis is bad code‚Äù, even if it‚Äôs your own!

üë™ Say ‚Äúwe‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúI‚Äù

An easy way to show people you‚Äôre open to their ideas is to say the words ‚Äúwe‚Äù and ‚Äúour‚Äù when you're talking about the code. It can set a collaborative tone when you're criticizing work and show that you both own the code.

Issues that come up in PR reviews aren't simple questions of right and wrong. When we communicate that way, it leads to defensiveness, hostility, and other impediments to teamwork.

3Ô∏è‚É£ "Guide-Driven Development"

Ryan didn't want to get ahead of himself when it came to feature development.

And he also wanted high-quality guides that wouldn't break when features changed.

So we tried a TDD approach, where guide content would be used as the test input.

Along with getting ideas for helpful guide content, we found some inspirations for features that an `init` command might do:

üôã Prompt the user for their project name and what to include
ü™Ñ List what files and folders were created
üíÅ Provide next commands a user might run

2Ô∏è‚É£ Reviewing comparable frameworks

Ryan wants devs who try Elm to have easy, familiar experiences that feel like the quick-start guides that popular frameworks have.

To do that, we looked to the JS community, to learn from the guides for these other frameworks.

After exploring a number of different potential audiences, we chose two that seemed like they'd be best served by Ryan's project:

üëÄ JS devs who want to easily evaluate Elm as an option
üå≥ Elm devs who want a simple, reliable app architecture

1Ô∏è‚É£ Defining the audience

Ryan wanted the docs to be great, but he needed more clarity on how to make that happen.

One solution to this problem is to ensure the menu is always rendered at a higher part of the DOM tree, where it is sure to be visible.

A solution like this needs to query for the intended size and positioning of the menu, because relative positioning will not be possible.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Making the menu visible above scrolling content

In CSS, scrolling containers have their overflow clipped. In cases where your dropdown is in a scrolling container, your menu may be partially hidden.

This can be done in pure Elm by decoding the click event to find HTML attributes of its target, but it is complex!

It can also be done in JS with a web component or a port.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Allowing clicks inside the menu

If your dropdown menu is designed to allow further click interactions inside the menu pane, the previous solution won't work.

You need a way for your global click Msg to determine whether the click was inside the menu or not.

Global click handlers can be attached to the application as subscriptions. 

Since choosing a menu option should close the menu, a global click subscriptions can produce a separate Msg that closes the menu.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Closing on click-away

One of the first issues you'll run into is how to close the menu in response to a click elsewhere on the page.

Otherwise, you'll have a dropdown menu that can only be closed by clicking on the toggle that opened it.

Implementing a dropdown menu in @elmlang is an unexpectedly deep topic!

üå≥ Elm's radical simplicity

Compared to "JavaScript fatigue", Elm includes best-in-class tools for:
‚Ä¢ Packages
‚Ä¢ Build tools
‚Ä¢ Frameworks
‚Ä¢ Type checking
‚Ä¢ Immutable data

And compared to other languages, Elm:
‚Ä¢ Doesn't use obscure FP jargon
‚Ä¢ Looks to remove features

‚úÖ The benefits of static types

‚Ä¢ Why not just auto-convert `Int` to `String`?
‚Ä¢ How `undefined` errors can propagate into user interfaces
‚Ä¢ Sources of undefined values can be hard to find
‚Ä¢ How Elm has no `null`, and what it uses instead

üèõ Overview of Elm's design

Kevin gives a clear explanation of:

‚Ä¢ The structure of an Elm program
‚Ä¢ Elm's friendly compiler errors and the educational material they include
‚Ä¢ How type annotations improve the error message from the compiler

ü§î Reasons for choosing Elm

Kevin gives the context in which his team at @CultureAmp decided to use Elm with their Rails backend.

Elm aligns with Ruby's value of developer happiness, and doesn't suffer from the same issues with backwards compatibility as JS.

Interested in @elmlang coming from a dynamic language?

You could hardly ask for a better introduction than Kevin Yank (@sentience) gives in his video "Developer Happiness on the Front End with Elm":

https://t.co/Q5kE2iRB3w

Interested in Elm? Take a look at my thread of resources for getting started:

https://t.co/RqRz99kMpX

ü™® Reliability

Ruby and Elm devs both want open-source code to be reliable‚Äîthey just go about it differently.

Ruby devs rely on test coverage and TDD to ensure their work is reliable.

Elm devs use the precision of the type system to make certain errors impossible to produce.

üé® Design culture

Ruby and Elm devs both want to make tools that are useful and beautiful.

Rubyists craft expressive DSLs that read naturally.

Elm devs design modules that are simple, clear, and unmistakable in their intent.

üõ§ Familiar conventions

The culture of "the Ruby Way", and "convention over configuration" helps Ruby devs communicate.

Elm shares these values through "The Elm Architecture", and by discouraging complicated solutions through the language's design.

‚ù§Ô∏è Kind leadership

The Ruby community says "Matz is nice and so we are nice" to describe Matz, the creator of Ruby.

I can't help but compare @evancz's similar qualities, expressed in his conference talks, the Elm guide, and even the friendly error messages from the compiler!

ü•∞ Happiness is a value

Elm is "a delightful language" in much the same way that Ruby is "optimized for programmer happiness".

Ruby makes developers happy with its natural and expressive syntax.

Elm's clear and simple design makes understanding and refactoring programs easy.

Developers seem to like arguing about statically typed versus dynamically typed languages.

But I like @elmlang for a lot of the same reasons I like @rubylangorg.

Here's why they aren't so different:
@MiguelCoba_ Thanks Miguel! I think opinions differ about extraction and its impact on readability, but I agree the risks are usually low.
@joelquen Thanks for sharing this generous and helpful example!

So extract a function if:

‚úÖ You're reusing code, or
‚úÖ Your code would be more easily skimmed

But avoid it if not.

‚õîÔ∏è It hides detail

The drawback is that an extracted function moves the details of the code to another place (the function definition).

This can break the flow of reading if you 're looking for a specific detail or following a chain of function calls.

3Ô∏è‚É£ It enables consistency

Subtly different from 2Ô∏è‚É£, an extracted function means changes to the function affect every usage in the same way.

If you copy-and-paste instead of extracting, you are setting yourself up for mistakes when one instance changes and another doesn't.

2Ô∏è‚É£ It allows for reuse

An obvious benefit of an extracted function is that you'll be able to call it in other places.

If your code needs to be used in two places, this benefit usually outweighs any drawbacks.

1Ô∏è‚É£ It summarizes code

By extracting a function, your function calls read as high-level summaries of what the code does.

This gives you opportunities to break your problems down into steps, and allow your solution to be read that way by others.

There are 3 benefits to extracting a function:

1Ô∏è‚É£ It summarizes code
2Ô∏è‚É£ It allows for reuse
3Ô∏è‚É£ It enables consistency

And there is 1 drawback:

‚õîÔ∏è It hides detail

Let's go into each of these one by one.

Extracting a function may be simple, but it's a great tool for clarifying your code.

But when should you do it, and when should you avoid it?

‚òùÔ∏è Fun fact

One thing I learned about Elm is that it doesn't do "dead code elimination".

Because it walks the tree from an entry point and follows function calls, unused code is not reachable. So "dead code" is never included in the first place!

6Ô∏è‚É£ Code generation

At this stage the compiler uses its optimized tree to generate the build target, resulting in an executable program.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Optimization

The compiler attempts to improve the performance of the code to be generated.

This could include:
‚Ä¢ Simplifying expressions if they are constant
‚Ä¢ Minifying identifier names
‚Ä¢ Removing unused code

4Ô∏è‚É£ Intermediate representation

Compilers may transform the resolved and type-checked tree into a form that is more agnostic of the source code or any particular build target.

This can prepare for optimization and code generation for multiple possible platforms.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Static analysis

Having parsed the source code into a tree, this is the point where a compiler attempts to "resolve" all of its "identifiers".

"Resolution" is answering questions like "Where is myVariable defined?"

This phase is also when type checking is done.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Parsing

A compiler parses this list of tokens into a tree structure called a syntax tree, that reflects the structure of the language.

If the tree can't be formed correctly, this is the point where a compiler would report syntax errors.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Scanning

Compilers start by reading source code and scanning it into a series of "tokens".

Tokens are the "parts of speech" of a language like:
‚Ä¢ numbers: 0, 3.14...
‚Ä¢ symbols: {, }, =, (, )...
‚Ä¢ identifiers: myVariable, myType...
‚Ä¢ reserved words: type, module...

ü§î When to write `andThen`?

Does `MyType` have a case where its type parameter is not present?

Will that type parameter's value need to be combined with another?

If so, consider writing `MyType.andThen`.

3Ô∏è‚É£ `andThen`

`andThen : (a -> MyType b) -> MyType a -> MyType b`

`andThen` allows combining values that might or might not be present.

Examples:
‚Ä¢ `Maybe.andThen` lets you map and combine `Maybe`s.
‚Ä¢ `List.concatMap` lets you map and combine `List`s.

ü§î When to write `andMap`?

Will `MyType`'s type parameter need to be constructed piece-by-piece using partial application?

For instance, is `MyType` is meant to be used for data validation or decoding?

If so, consider writing `MyType.andMap`.

2Ô∏è‚É£ andMap

`andMap : MyType a -> MyType (a -> b) -> MyType b`

`andMap` allows a type variable to be a function whose arguments are partially applied.

Example:
‚Ä¢ `Json.Decode.Pipeline.required` lets you define fields to be decoded, one by one, via pipeline application.

ü§î When to write `map`?

Will `MyType` be parameterized with types that commonly need functions applied to them, like `msg`?

If so, consider writing `https://t.co/Y5Shu6jiOz`.

1Ô∏è‚É£ map

`map : (a -> b) -> MyType a -> MyType b`

`map` applies a function to a type's parameter.

Examples:
‚Ä¢ `https://t.co/YYPqVikyKH` applies a function to `Just` values of a `Maybe`
‚Ä¢ `https://t.co/CgS2i90wP1` lets you transform the `msg` type produced by `Html msg`

For you FP jargon-heads out there, I learned an unfold is called an "anamorphism".

I won't be saying that too much, but do what you will with that knowledge: https://t.co/3u01QWFCiJ

This can be used for generating a list of values from a data source.

Here's an implementation of `unfold`, and a sample program that generates a range of integers:
https://t.co/IQw8w93BRL

`unfold` does the opposite.

It takes:
‚Ä¢ A function for generating new values
‚Ä¢ An initial data type (e.g. `Tree`, `List`)

And returns:
‚Ä¢ A list of values

unfold : (a -> Maybe (b, a)) -> a -> List b

Where `fold` takes:
‚Ä¢ A reducing function
‚Ä¢ An initial data type (e.g. `Tree`, `List`)
‚Ä¢ A list

And returns:
‚Ä¢ A new data type with all the list values reduced into it.

foldl : (a -> b -> b) -> b -> List a -> b

If you write @elmlang, you may have worked with fold functions like `List.foldl`.

‚òùÔ∏è Use the simplest pattern you can

It can be tempting to treat your view code as uniform "components".

But there's no need to use 4Ô∏è‚É£ for everything‚Äîin many cases it would be too much work!

Remember: there is no such thing as "parent-child communication" with pure functions.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Returning ParentMsg

`view : Model -> Html Msg`
`update : Msg -> Model -> (Model, Cmd Msg, Maybe ParentMsg)`

Use this pattern when a view needs to send data to an `update` function above it in the hierarchy.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Model, Msg, update

`view : Model -> Html Msg`
`update : Msg -> Model -> (Model, Cmd Msg)`

Create a `Msg` type and use this pattern when there are too many parameters (data and `msg`s) to pass in.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Config parameter

`view : Config msg -> Html msg`

Create a `Config` type and use this pattern when some parameters are optional, or could benefit from sensible defaults.

More about the Config pattern:
https://t.co/jiNbdmgNk7

1Ô∏è‚É£ Simple parameters

`view : String -> (String -> msg) -> Html msg`

Use this when view code varies in few ways, and all parameters are required.

üß† Question teaching FP "foundations"

Academic concepts like monads and the lambda calculus don't necessarily help students grasp FP.

Teaching these ideas as a rite of passage is not necessarily effective.

Anjana starts by helping students identify pure vs. impure functions.

üßë‚Äçüè´ You don't have to be an expert to teach FP

Anjana describes a popular Unconference talk she gave in 2016 on FP as a beginner, that resonated with a huge number of people (2.3 million views on YouTube).

So people can be very receptive to relatable lessons from a beginner!

üîß FP is one tool, not the only tool

FP has its enthusiasts in the programming community.

But you don't have to be dogmatic about FP as a "superior" way of doing programming. Not all code needs to be converted to functional style in all languages in order to be more effective.

‚ùì What is functional programming?

Definitions of FP vary! Some older definitions require point-free style. Others focus on the broader use of pure functions.

Anjana helpfully defines a goal of FP as moving side effects to the boundary of your program.

Walking through a use case step-by‚Ä¶

Curious about this method? I learned it from Steve Krug's usability testing book "Rocket Surgery Made Easy".

Learn more about it at https://t.co/F2LUh09nG6

üìù Take notes and address the issues

What parts of your design confused your participant? What connections weren't they able to make? What parts were missing? Where did they get stuck?

Write these problems down. Then, make the simplest changes you can that would solve them.

ü§´ Observe, don't explain

You may be tempted to explain how your design works and why it's so clever.

Resist this temptation! Only explain what you need to get them unstuck.

Otherwise, you won't learn anything about how people use it when you're not there to explain.

üëÄ Watch the participant attempt the task

Ask your participant to implement the example use case you thought of. Ask them to think aloud as they do it.

Clarify that you're testing the code, not them, and that it's fine if they make mistakes or get confused.

üôã Find a participant

Find a dev you work with, a friend from the software community, etc. who's willing to try out your code.

The more likely that they'd actually be using the code you wrote for their work, the better.

üîç Choose a use case to test

Think of an example implementation your code would likely be used to write. 

Get concrete, to the point where you could explain the goal to a programmer and ask them to attempt it.

Is your latest module well-designed and nice to use? How do you know?

Don't take your own word for it! Test your code on other programmers who would use it.

üç± Organize with doc comments

Organizing your exposed types in logical groupings is a great way to help your code's users get their bearings before they read the documentation.

`elm-format` arranges your exposures accordingly when you use `@docs` in your doc-comments.

üß† Take advantage of conventions

Interfaces are forms of communication‚Äîbe consistent with conventions that users of your code are likely to know!

For instance, In Elm, models are usually named `Model`, are initialized with an `init` function, updated with `update`, etc.

üéØ Functions should relate to your central type

If you find yourself writing functions prefixed with another type's name (e.g. `monthToString`, `monthFromDate`), this is a likely sign that these belong with the `Month` type in in a new module.

üß≥ Avoid exposing all variants of a type

If client code is able to destructure your type or use variants directly, your interface will be less durable.

There are exceptions, but as a general rule, instead of `Calendar(..)`, provide your interface through functions.

‚òùÔ∏è Start with a type

Your module should be named after the type it's "about". 

For instance, a `Calendar.elm` module should be about a `Calendar` datatype and its associated helper functions.

üß• Don't expose everything

A good module interface is intentional. So don't use `exposing (..)`. 

Choose what should be exposed, and what shouldn't.
